title: A Compact Imaging Platform for Conducting C. elegans Phenotypic Assays on Earth and in Spaceflight
background: C. elegans is used for fundamental biological studies, drug screening, disease modeling, and space-biology investigations. These applications rely on whole-organism phenotypic assays involving animal behavior and locomotion. Spaceflight experiments face constraints including payload size, weight, crew time, and safety requirements.
objective: To develop a compact imaging platform (CIP) integrated with a smart-device camera for whole-organism phenotyping of C. elegans that addresses spaceflight constraints while maintaining research capabilities.
methods: A 3D-printed compact imaging platform was designed with no external optical elements and no mechanical focusing requirement. The system uses an iPod Touch camera with a third-party app for autofocusing and video acquisition. Validation included behavioral assays on agar plates, liquid droplets, and microfluidic chips with wild-type and mutant C. elegans strains.
results: The CIP successfully acquired phenotypic data from multiple substrates, with results consistent with literature values. Temperature control within 0.5°C was achieved. Mutant studies distinguished phenotypic differences between strains. The system demonstrated compatibility with standard image analysis software.
conclusion: The CIP is a simple, versatile, low-cost, small-footprint phenotyping tool suitable for C. elegans assays on Earth and adaptable for space biology research on the ISS after appropriate certification.

learning_notes.note: The Compact Imaging Platform (CIP) measures 7.5″×4.5″×5.5″, weighs ≈700g, and requires only 3W power via USB, making it suitable for ISS constraints where payload size and weight are critical factors. This represents a significant reduction compared to standard microscopy systems.

The CIP achieved temperature control within 0.5°C of set points (15°C, 20°C, 25°C) using active cooling and ventilation slots, addressing a critical requirement for C. elegans assays where behavior is temperature-sensitive and ISS experiments require precise environmental control.

Validation studies showed the CIP produced phenotypic data consistent with literature values: wild-type C. elegans exhibited forward speeds of ≈0.14 mm/s on plates and ≈2.30 mm/s in liquid, with body wave frequencies of ≈0.39 Hz and ≈1.68 Hz respectively, confirming system reliability.

The system successfully distinguished mutant phenotypes, with unc-32(e189) showing severe swim defects (thrashing frequency ≈0.07 vs wild-type ≈1.57) and unc-79(e1068) showing intermediate defects (≈1.29), demonstrating capability for genetic studies in space-relevant formats.

Multiple CIP units can operate in parallel powered by a single USB hub and housed in standard incubators, enabling high-throughput studies within ISS constraints. This parallel operation capability addresses the need for statistical power in space biology experiments with limited resources.

The CIP is compatible with three key C. elegans substrates: agar plates, liquid droplets on glass slides, and microfluidic chips, providing flexibility for different assay types. This versatility is crucial for spaceflight where multiple experiment types may be conducted with limited hardware.

The smart-device approach reduces crew training requirements since astronauts are already familiar with smartphone interfaces, and integrated data storage (up to 250GB) minimizes data transfer needs - both critical advantages for ISS operations where crew time and bandwidth are limited resources.
